entry.title: MATH 407: Probability Theory
entry.content:
Description

  • Intructor: Dr. Sergey Lototsky
  • Objective: To learn the basics of probability so that you are prepared for statistics (math 408). Some particular topics to master are (a) Law of Large Numbers (LLN) (b) Central Limit Theorem (CLT) (c) Normal (Gaussian) distribution (d) Poisson approximation.

I did not attend all the lectures (in fact, never go to lectures), thus don’t have a complete set of notes. I will try to fill in the gaps as I go along. However, I do have the Computer Project for this course, feel free to check it out.

entry.title: MATH 430: Thoery of Numbers
entry.content:
Description

  • Intructor: Masoud Zargar
  • Course description: This is a course on (elementary) number theory, covering the basic problems with which this subject deals, as well as how it is related to other areas of mathematics. Throughout the course, I will also inspire some abstract mathematics that has been developed to generalize some related classical concepts. We will try to follow the first 9 chapters of the textbook, with some deviations into analytic number theory and very basic abstract algebra.

Syllabus

If you could not preview, download here: MATH430_Syllabus.pdf

Personal Comments

MATH430, especially instructed by Professor Zargar, is an excellent proof-based course for beginners. However, Professor Zargar does not “curve up” on the exams; during the 2022 Fall semester, he curved down the grade. Specifically, you need to get approximately 97% on the final grade to get an A, which is intended to have 4 out of 40 students get an A (though it does not affect my grade). Thus, be prepared to take notes, do bonus problems on the homework, and try to understand the proofs and materials. You will learn much if you put in the effort, and I highly recommend the course.

entry.title: MATH 226: Calculus III
entry.content:
Description

  • Intructor: Dr. Guillaume Dreyer
  • Course Coentent: space curve, surface, curvature, function of several variables, partial derivatives, multiple integral, line integral, surface integral, Stokes’ Theorem and its ap- plications.

MATH 226: Calculus III by Prof. Guillaume Dreyer is indeed hard in some extend, but what you need to do is just practice and practice. Read the books and notes, and do all the past exams. You will be fine.
